Relationships and dependencies among pixels of an image can be leveraged to improve semantic segmentation accuracy. This paper presents a self-attention semantic segmentation method applied to UA imagery to assess damage caused by natural disasters. The proposed method outperforms four state-of-the-art segmentation methods both quantitatively and qualitatively, achieving a mean IoU score of 84.03%.

Introduction

In recent years, numerous natural disasters have caused significant personal injuries and economic losses worldwide. In 2020, the United States experienced 22 natural disasters, resulting in approximately $96.4 billion in damages. Current tropical storms are persisting longer and causing more damage than in the past. For example, in 2017, Hurricane Harvey inundated Houston, Texas, with 127 billion tons of water. Moisture from warm and tropical oceans fuels hurricanes, driving intense winds. Due to climate change, the air over oceans can hold more moisture, intensifying storms at sea. Consequently, when these storms reach land, they should decay quickly due to the lack of fuel from the seas. However, the timescale of decay of North Atlantic land-falling hurricanes has almost doubled over the past 50 years due to climate change. This slower decay is fueled by an increased amount of moisture stored in the hurricane from its passage over the ocean prior to landfall.

Proper damage assessment during and after a natural disaster is crucial for facilitating rescue efforts. Semantic segmentation, a fundamental task in computer vision, involves assigning semantic labels to each pixel of an image. It can aid in rescue efforts by providing quick and accurate damage assessments. Deep Convolutional Neural Networks (DCNNs) have gained popularity in semantic segmentation due to their improved performance compared to traditional computer vision techniques.

Besides non-disaster scenarios, DCNNs are being utilized by researchers in natural disaster damage assessment. Various DCNN semantic segmentation methods have been proposed, including encoder-decoder and pyramid-based methods. Self-attention based methods have also shown excellent performance, capturing spatial dependencies between feature maps and contributing to mutual improvement.

In this work, we implement a self-attention based semantic segmentation method named ReDNetPlus on the natural disaster dataset FloodNet. Our results demonstrate that our method outperforms four other segmentation methods, including both attention and non-attention based methods. This suggests that our approach is feasible and promising.

Related Works

Semantic segmentation methods can be classified into three categories: encoder-decoder based methods, pyramid pooling based methods, and attention based methods. Encoder-decoder based methods, such as U-Net, adopt local context from middle and lower level features through an encoder-decoder architecture. These methods generate sharp object boundaries or small details based on local context and make high-resolution predictions. On the other hand, pyramid-based modules create a hierarchical representation of the image, allowing for more accurate predictions.
